questions.text:
A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 27 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well, apart from increasing fatigue and mild swelling of her legs, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Medical history is remarkable for epilepsy treated with lamotrigine. Her sister had preeclampsia during her last pregnancy. Immunizations are up-to-date. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with 27 weeks' gestation. There is 1+ pitting edema at the ankles bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
91 μm3



Leukocyte count
5100/mm3



Platelet count
131,000/mm3


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order coagulation studies and liver chemistries
Order urine dipstick and ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
Discontinue lamotrigine and initiate valproate therapy
Reassure the patient and schedule a follow-up appointment
Initiate dexamethasone and refer to hematology

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coagulation studies and liver chemistries are used to evaluate for other causes of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy, such as severe preeclampsia, HELLP, and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. These conditions usually manifest with platelets < 100,000/mm3 and other characteristic features (e.g., hypertension in severe preeclampsia, anemia in HELLP, neurological manifestations in TTP). This patient is asymptomatic and only has mild thrombocytopenia, which makes GT more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine dipstick and blood pressure monitoring are used in the workup for preeclampsia. Preeclampsia with severe features may manifest with thrombocytopenia. This patient does not have elevated blood pressure, and thrombocytopenia in preeclampsia with severe features is usually < 100,000/mm3, which makes this condition unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain anticonvulsants, such as valproate, can cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Lamotrigine is generally considered safe to use in pregnancy and does not usually cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Therefore, discontinuing lamotrigine in favor of valproate is not appropriate. Furthermore, drug-induced thrombocytopenia is usually severe (< 20,000 mm3).

D) CORRECT:

GT is a common, benign, self-limited condition that is likely due to increased circulatory volume during pregnancy (i.e., dilutional thrombocytopenia) and consumption and pooling of platelets in the placenta. GT can occur in any trimester but is more common during the second half of pregnancy. As there is no increased risk of bleeding, associated blood count abnormalities, or fetal or neonatal thrombocytopenia in patients with GT, reassurance and follow-up are sufficient. Further workup to assess for more serious causes, such as immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), preeclampsia, or HELLP, is indicated in symptomatic patients or those with more severe thrombocytopenia (< 100,000/mm3). GT does not require any treatment or change in prenatal care and delivery.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids and referral to hematology for monitoring and counseling are indicated for patients with immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), which often causes no symptoms and cannot be excluded in this patient. However, corticosteroids are only indicated in asymptomatic adults with a platelet count < 30,000/mm3. Moreover, ITP typically manifests with a more severely decreased platelet count (< 100,000/mm3), making this diagnosis less likely.
questions.hint: Isolated mild thrombocytopenia (≥ 100,000/mm3) in an asymptomatic pregnant patient should raise concern for gestational thrombocytopenia (GT).

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents to the emergency department with red streaking on her right arm. She grazed the arm 2 days ago and stopped minimal bleeding from the wound by applying local pressure. She reports a fever of 38.7°C.
She has a platelet count of 243,000 per mm3 (reference range, 150,000–350,000). She is started on intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone. She is then hospitalized, improves quickly, and is discharged on day 3.
Five days after discharge, the patient notices a petechial rash on her legs and presents again for evaluation. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin concentration of 11.4 g/dL (reference range, 12.0–16.0), a leukocyte count of 4200 per mm3 (4500–11,000), a platelet count of 18,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000), a normal partial thromboplastin time and prothrombin time, normal fibrinogen levels, and normal renal function.
Review of the peripheral-blood smear reveals marked reduction of the platelet count but normal platelet morphology. No schistocytes are present.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s thrombocytopenia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) has a classic pentad: fever, acute kidney failure, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and altered mental status. Although TTP does not often manifest with all five characteristics, this patient’s normal coagulation parameters, normal hemoglobin level, and normal renal function argue against this diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia is a common laboratory abnormality in hospitalized patients and is most commonly caused by medications. More than 100 agents have been implicated in drug-induced thrombocytopenia; among those most frequently cited are heparin, quinine, and some antibiotics. In a large case series of vancomycin-treated patients who then developed thrombocytopenia, vancomycin-dependent platelet-reactive antibodies were identified.

Key learning point: In an inpatient who has received vancomycin and ceftriaxone, the most likely cause of a new thrombocytopenia that develops during or shortly after hospitalization is drug-induced thrombocytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is possible but unlikely in a patient who is improving clinically and has normal coagulation parameters.

D) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency is a cause of thrombocytopenia but would not cause thrombocytopenia that developed acutely.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenia is unlikely to develop this acutely during or shortly after hospitalization in a patient who presents with a normal platelet count.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man is found to have a low platelet count on a routine complete blood count. The laboratory technician reports evidence of platelet clumping on the peripheral-blood smear.
The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He is treated with rivaroxaban, lisinopril, and simvastatin. He also takes quinine for intermittent leg cramps.
He reports no history of illicit drug use, sexual intercourse without condoms, or blood transfusions. There is no known history of a familial bleeding disorder.
His temperature is 37.3°C, his blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 84 beats per minute. His examination is unremarkable, and hepatosplenomegaly, ecchymoses, and petechiae are absent.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
6500
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
15.1
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)
45
41–53



Platelet count (per mm3)
10,000
150,000–350,000


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
150
100–190


His coagulation studies are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quinine-induced thrombocytopenia is not typically associated with platelet clumping on blood smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is not present, given the patient's normal coagulation studies.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenia is usually associated with bruising or bleeding. It is not associated with platelet clumping on peripheral-blood smear.

D) CORRECT:

The findings of thrombocytopenia, lack of bruising or bleeding, and a peripheral-blood smear showing platelet clumping are consistent with pseudothrombocytopenia. Pseudothrombocytopenia (occurring in 0.1% of the population) is caused by naturally occurring antibodies directed against an epitope on glycoprotein IIb/IIIa that is exposed by the anticoagulant ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid. Collection of the sample in a tube with the alternative anticoagulant (citrate or heparin) will usually prevent the platelet clumping.

Key learning point: Severe thrombocytopenia in a patient who has no signs of bruising or bleeding, has normal clotting studies, and has a peripheral-blood smear that reveals platelet clumping without other abnormalities is suggestive of pseudothrombocytopenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is typically associated with schistocytes on blood smear, as well as an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for new thrombocytopenia. She was hospitalized 20 days ago with pyelonephritis and received intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam for the pyelonephritis and enoxaparin for deep-vein thrombosis prophylaxis. She was discharged 11 days ago, at which time she started a course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Her only other medication is omeprazole, which she has taken for several years.
Her vital signs are within normal limits. Her only current symptom is easy bruising. She does not have any leg swelling or other symptoms of thrombosis.
Her platelet count was 155,000 per mm3 (reference range, 150,000–350,000) at hospital discharge and is now 14,000 per mm3 . Other current laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.2
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4200
4500–11,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.6–1.1


Which one of the following medications or conditions is the most likely cause of the patient's low platelet count?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sepsis can lead to thrombocytopenia, but the patient currently has normal vital signs and no symptoms of sepsis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is always a concern, it is unlikely in this case, given the patient’s 4Ts score. This score takes into account the (1) degree of thrombocytopenia, (2) the timing of the decline in platelet count, (3) the development of thrombosis or other sequelae, and (4) the presence of other causes for thrombocytopenia. This patient has 1 point for the degree of thrombocytopenia (the platelet count dropped by >50%, but the nadir is <20,000 per mm3), 1 point for timing, 0 for thrombosis, and 1 point for other causes, giving her a total score of 3. This score is associated with a low probability for HIT.

C) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole can lead to thrombocytopenia, but it would be uncommon for a chronic medication to lead to new thrombocytopenia.

D) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin-tazobactam is not associated with late-onset thrombocytopenia. Although this medication could cause drug-induced immune-mediated thrombocytopenia, it would need to be continually present to induce ongoing thrombocytopenia. If this patient’s piperacillin-tazobactam, which was stopped 11 days ago, was the cause of her thrombocytopenia, the platelet count would have been expected to improve by now.

E) CORRECT:

Drug-induced immune thrombocytopenia is an underrecognized cause of thrombocytopenia. The thrombocytopenia develops a median of 5 to 10 days after drug exposure and can become severe (<20,000 platelets per mm3). Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is a common culprit, as are quinine, vancomycin, and penicillin. In this patient, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the most likely culprit and should be discontinued.

Determining the Likelihood of Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia:

Although heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is always a concern, it is unlikely in this case, given the patient’s 4Ts score. This score takes into account the (1) degree of thrombocytopenia, (2) the timing of the decline in platelet count, (3) the development of thrombosis or other sequelae, and (4) the presence of other causes for thrombocytopenia.

This patient has 1 point for the degree of thrombocytopenia (the platelet count dropped by >50%, but the nadir is <20,000 per mm3), 1 point for timing, 0 for thrombosis, and 1 point for other causes, giving her a total score of 3. This score is associated with a low probability for HIT.

Key learning point: The timing of the onset of drug-induced immune-mediated thrombocytopenia is a median of 5 to 10 days after exposure to the medication.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old previously healthy man reports gingival bleeding after brushing his teeth. He also reports pinpoint purple "dots" on the periocular area after an episode of vomiting. He started taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a cellulitis one week before these episodes. He has had no recent fevers or upper respiratory tract infections.
Which one of the following tests would be most likely to reveal the cause of this patient’s skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Testing for activated partial thromboplastin time is typically used to detect coagulation disorders such as clotting-factor deficiencies, defects, or inhibitors. Patients with coagulation disorders typically present with large ecchymoses and deep hematomas. Often, the bleeding associated with coagulation disorders is delayed, whereas patients with thrombocytopenia tend to bleed immediately.

B) CORRECT:

A low platelet count and defects in platelet function may manifest clinically as petechiae or mucosal bleeding. Petechiae are recognizable by their pinpoint size and nonblanching purple color. Valsalva maneuvers, such as coughing, defecating, or vomiting, can induce petechiae on the face in a patient with thrombocytopenia. There are many causes of thrombocytopenia, but drug-induced thrombocytopenia and immune thrombocytopenia are among the most common. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is among the medications that can induce acute thrombocytopenia.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of petechiae and gingival bleeding is thrombocytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Testing for prothrombin time is typically used to detect coagulation disorders such as clotting-factor deficiencies, defects, or inhibitors. Patients with coagulation disorders typically present with large ecchymoses and deep hematomas. Often, the bleeding associated with coagulation disorders is delayed, whereas patients with thrombocytopenia tend to bleed immediately.

D) INCORRECT:

The direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is used to detect autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which does not manifest with petechiae or mucosal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand factor plays a crucial role in hemostasis by binding platelets to endothelial surfaces. It also contributes to fibrin clot formation, serving as a carrier protein for factor VIII. Because of its role in binding platelets, a deficiency in von Willebrand factor can manifest as petechiae. However, it is typically not acute in onset and would not be induced by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman who is recovering from a hysterectomy for uterine fibroids, complicated by wound cellulitis, is found on postoperative day 8 to have a platelet count of 9000 per mm3 (reference range, 150,000–350,000; preoperative value, 200,000). The rest of her complete blood count is normal. She has been receiving prophylactic dalteparin for 8 days and has no previous history of exposure to heparin. In addition, she has been treated with vancomycin for 5 days for a wound infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Her other current medications are omeprazole and zolpidem.
On physical examination, she has normal vital signs, including a heart rate of 76 beats per minute and an oxygen saturation of 97% while she breathes ambient air. Skin examination is notable for petechiae. Some oozing from the surgical site is evident. There is no leg swelling.
Her peripheral blood smear shows no schistocytes or other findings that would suggest a microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Her prothrombin time is 12.0 seconds (11.1–13.1), her partial thromboplastin time is 25.0 seconds (22.1–35.1), and her serum lactate dehydrogenase level is normal.
What laboratory evaluation for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), if any, is indicated for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The heparin-induced platelet aggregation (HIPA) assay and the serotonin release assay (SRA) are functional assays that test the ability of a patient’s HIT antibodies to activate test platelets. Both tests are considered more specific than immunoassays for detecting clinically relevant antibodies, but they are not used in the initial evaluation for HIT: the HIPA assay has low sensitivity, and the SRA assay, although highly sensitive and highly specific, is technically demanding and not routinely available at most centers.

These tests are typically ordered only when there is an indeterminate result on an immunoassay or when the pretest probability and the immunoassay are discordant (e.g., a high 4Ts score with a negative ELISA result).

B) INCORRECT:

Additional testing for HIT is not typically indicated in a patient with a low pretest probability of HIT, because a positive result is likely to be a false positive. This is especially true for the most common initial test for HIT, an enzyme-linked immunosorbent immunoassay (ELISA) that identifies the presence of antiplatelet factor 4 antibodies in serum. This test is very sensitive (91% to 97%), but the specificity can vary considerably: it may exceed 90% if the optical density (OD) is >2.00, but it plummets at OD values of 0.40 to 2.00, which are common and considered indeterminate.

C) INCORRECT:

The heparin-induced platelet aggregation (HIPA) assay and the serotonin release assay (SRA) are functional assays that test the ability of a patient’s HIT antibodies to activate test platelets. Both tests are considered more specific than immunoassays for detecting clinically relevant antibodies, but they are not used in the initial evaluation for HIT: the HIPA assay has low sensitivity, and the SRA assay, although highly sensitive and highly specific, is technically demanding and not routinely available at most centers.

These tests are typically ordered only when there is an indeterminate result on an immunoassay or when the pretest probability and the immunoassay are discordant (e.g., a high 4Ts score with a negative ELISA result).

D) INCORRECT:

The ADAMTS13 assay is used during the workup of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). In an acute episode of TTP, the ADAMTS13 enzyme’s activity level is usually <10%. This assay has no role in assessing HIT.

E) CORRECT:

This patient likely has drug-induced thrombocytopenia from vancomycin. Vancomycin-induced thrombocytopenia often starts after around 5 days of treatment, with a mean nadir platelet count of 13,600 per mm3 occurring 8 days after initiation of treatment. Vancomycin-induced thrombocytopenia generally results in bleeding problems rather than thrombosis.

Vancomycin should be stopped in this patient. Generally, patients with drug-induced thrombocytopenia recover within one week of discontinuing the offending agent. They may require platelet transfusion depending on their clinical recovery and repeat platelet measurements.

This patient has a low likelihood of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), and further testing is not indicated. HIT usually occurs 5 to 14 days after exposure (earlier in those with prior heparin exposure) and does not generally reduce platelet counts to below 10,000 per mm3 . Furthermore, low-molecular-weight heparin is much less likely to cause HIT than unfractionated heparin.

Assessing the Pretest Likelihood of HIT:

The 4Ts scoring system is often used to help quantify the pretest likelihood of HIT. The 4Ts system assesses (1) the extent of the thrombocytopenia, (2) the timing of the decline in platelet count after heparin exposure, (3) the development of thrombosis or other sequelae of HIT, and (4) other potential causes of the thrombocytopenia.

This patient's 4Ts score is only 3 (on an 8-point scale), consistent with a low pretest probability of HIT. Her score is determined as follows:

• No points for the degree of thrombocytopenia because her platelet count nadir is <10,000 per mm3
• 2 points for the timing of the thrombocytopenia because it occurred 5 to 10 days after the initial heparin exposure
• No points for thrombosis because she has no evidence of this
• 1 point for other potential causes because there is another likely explanation for the thrombocytopenia — vancomycin use

Before ordering a diagnostic test, clinicians should be familiar with the characteristics of the test they are considering and should assess the estimated pretest likelihood of disease based on the patient’s history and clinical findings. If the pretest likelihood of disease is very low, a positive test result is more likely to be a false positive (especially if the test has low specificity); similarly, if the pretest probability of disease is very high, a negative test result is likely to be a false negative (especially if the test has low sensitivity).

Key learning point: The validated 4Ts scoring system helps to assess the pretest probability of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia in a patient recently exposed to heparin.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus reports increased bleeding. For the past several months, her periods have been heavier than usual, and she has been bruising easily. She also notes that her gums sometimes bleed after she brushes her teeth.
She reports no fevers, chills, diarrhea, or any change in weight.
Her vital signs are normal, and her lungs are clear. Her abdominal examination is unremarkable, with no masses or organomegaly. She has no arthritis, and her extremities are warm and well perfused. She has a fine, pinpoint, nonblanching, red rash on her legs, arms, and soft palate. She has several bruises on her shins but nowhere else.
A urinalysis shows 1+ blood and 2+ protein.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency, factor VII deficiency, and von Willebrand syndrome can all manifest with an increase in bleeding, but thrombocytopenia is the more common hematologic abnormality in a patient with SLE.

B) INCORRECT:

Lupus anticoagulant, an antibody that leads to a prolonged prothrombin time or partial-thromboplastin time, causes an increase in clotting, not bleeding. Patients with lupus anticoagulant typically present with pulmonary embolism or deep-vein thrombosis. They often have mild-to-moderate thrombocytopenia from consumption of platelets, but rarely does the thrombocytopenia become severe.

C) CORRECT:

Mild thrombocytopenia is relatively common in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). More severe thrombocytopenia can manifest as easy bruising, spontaneous bleeding from the gums, blood in the stool or urine, internal bleeding, prolonged bleeding from cuts, and petechiae. Petechiae are the most specific finding of thrombocytopenia; they are caused by microhemorrhages under the skin and can never be considered normal.

Vitamin K deficiency, factor VII deficiency, and von Willebrand syndrome can all manifest with an increase in bleeding, but thrombocytopenia is the more common hematologic abnormality in a patient with SLE.

Key learning point: The most prominent clinical finding of thrombocytopenia is the presence of petechiae.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency, factor VII deficiency, and von Willebrand syndrome can all manifest with an increase in bleeding, but thrombocytopenia is the more common hematologic abnormality in a patient with SLE.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency, factor VII deficiency, and von Willebrand syndrome can all manifest with an increase in bleeding, but thrombocytopenia is the more common hematologic abnormality in a patient with SLE.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of easy bruising and fatigue. She denies fever, weight loss, or recent medications. Examination shows scattered petechiae on her legs and small ecchymoses on her arms. There is no mucosal bleeding, lymphadenopathy, or organomegaly. Platelet count is 38,000/mm³. Hemoglobin, white blood cells, and coagulation studies are normal. Peripheral smear shows isolated thrombocytopenia without schistocytes. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Arrange outpatient follow-up with repeat CBC in 1–4 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeating CBC in 1–4 weeks is appropriate for asymptomatic patients with platelet counts above 50,000/mm³. This patient has mild bleeding symptoms and a platelet count below this threshold.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Mildly symptomatic patients with platelet counts below 50,000/mm³ require hematology consultation. The patient's petechiae and easy bruising represent mild bleeding symptoms, and her platelet count falls below the threshold requiring specialist evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Platelet transfusion is used for patients with neurological symptoms, significant bleeding, or those requiring urgent procedures. Prophylactic transfusion is typically only considered at much lower counts (< 10,000/mm³) than are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric corticosteroids can be considered for suspected immune thrombocytopenia, but are typically only given when platelet counts are below 30,000/mm³.

E) INCORRECT:

IVIG is used in emergency management of thrombocytopenia when an immune cause is suspected. Emergency management is indicated for patients with neurological symptoms, anticipated urgent surgery or invasive procedures, or significant bleeding.
